Although heteroatom doped Fe-based catalysts have made significant process in CO2 hydrogenation, designing a tailor-made catalyst with excellent catalytic performance remains a challenge. In this work, a series of heteroatom doped Na-FeM/ZrO2 (M = Ga, Mn, Zn, Co, and In) catalysts were prepared by the urea self-combustion method. Meanwhile, the structure and physicochemical properties of these catalysts were analyzed by various characterizations. In detail, Zn doping was more favorable for light olefin production. Na-FeZn/ZrO2 catalysts exhibited CO2 conversion of 31.3 % and light olefins selectivity of 41.4 % with olefins/paraffins (O/P) ratio of 4.93. H2-TPR and in situ XRD results revealed that Zn promoted reduction of the catalyst and the formation of ZnO species, which inhibited the secondary hydrogenation of the generated olefins. This work contributes to the development of novel catalysts for efficient CO2 hydrogenation via understanding the relationship between structure and catalytic performance. Graphical Abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Fe-based catalysts Heteroatom Product distribution Physicochemical properties Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the social and economic development of mankind, the rapid consumption of non-renewable energy sources has led to high CO2 emissions, causing a series of environmental problems [1–3]. To reduce CO2 emissions and respond to the national policy, the conversion of CO2 into high value-added products has become a current research hotspot. Examples include CO2 hydrogenation to methane [4,5], methanol [6,7], ethanol [8,9], olefins [10] and gasoline [11,12]. Among them, light olefins (C2 =–C4 =) are used in the production of plastics, polymer, and pharmaceuticals [13], etc. Meanwhile, the heavy hydrocarbons are widely used as fuels and important chemical feedstock [14]. CO2 is a non-polar symmetric molecule with a high initial ionization energy (13.79 eV) [15]. Therefore, catalysts are commonly used to catalyze CO2 hydrogenation reactions. Fe-based catalysts with both reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS) and C-C coupling reaction active sites are often widely used in CO2 hydrogenation rather than Co- and Ru-based catalysts [16]. Generally, single Fe catalysts without any promoters have poor catalytic activity and products selectivity. Thus, alkali metal promoter has been commonly used to modify Fe-based catalysts. The addition of Na and K could increase the surface basicity of the Fe-based catalyst, which promoted CO2 adsorption and activation and modulated the electronic properties of the catalyst to facilitate the generation of the active phase [17–19]. Furthermore, bimetallic catalysts have been widely used along with Fe-based catalysts to improve the activity and selectivity of the target product. During the synthesis of these catalysts, a second metal promoter is added to generate specific metal oxides, which could regulate the reduction and adsorption capacity of the catalysts, thus improving catalytic performance. Such as Zn [20,21], Mg [22,23], Mn [24,25] and Cu [26,27]. Zn promoter enhances the desorption of primary olefins and inhibits the formation of alkanes [28]. Furthermore, ZnFe2O4 facilitated catalyst activation of CO, and the addition of Zn promoted the reduction and carbonization of Fe oxides [18,29]. Basic Mg promotes the reduction and carbonization of the catalyst to produce more active sites [30,31]. Mn can be used as an electronic and structural aid to promote CO activation and dispersion of Fe active sites [32]. Wang et al. [33] found that Mn could promote the formation of Fe3C and improve the selectivity of light olefins. Research results has demonstrated that promotional effect of Cu is closely related to its existing form. For instance, the existence of CuO weakens the basicity of iron sites, leading to an increase in light olefins selectivity [34], while the generation of CuFeO2 facilitates C-C coupling during the CO2 hydrogenation [35]. Catalyst supports can disperse and anchor reactive active sites, improving catalyst activity. Common supports include Al2O3 [36,37], SiO2 [38,39], and ZrO2 [40,41]. By comparing different supports (CNT, Al2O3, SiO2, ZrO2), Tu et al. [42] discovered that the high C/H ratio on the surface of spent catalyst contributes to the generation of olefins. They found ZrO2 promotes the adsorption of CO2 and CO and inhibits the adsorption of H2, which in turn inhibits the secondary hydrogenation of generated olefins. Urea self-combustion method is a common technique for the synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts. The catalyst formed by the urea combustion method will have low carbon residues [43], which contributes to the stability of the catalyst. It will also reduce sintering, agglomeration phenomenon, and it is easier to maintain a smaller particle size [44] with higher specific surface area compared to co-precipitation. Previously, the effects of different metal promoters on Fe-based catalysts during CO2 hydrogenation have been studied, but the effects of common promoters on the Fe/ZrO2 system are not clear. To design and utilize Fe-based catalysts more rationally, a series of Fe-based catalysts modified with various metals and Na using ZrO2 as a support were prepared by urea self-combustion method and utilized for CO2 hydrogenation. The study investigated the impact of different metal promoters on the product distribution of CO2 hydrogenation over Fe-based catalysts, as well as on the strong interactions of Fe-ZrO2 through various characterization methods. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Na-FeM/ZrO2 (M = Ga, Mn, Zn, Co, and In) catalysts were prepared by urea self-combustion method. In a typical synthesis of Na-FeZn/ZrO2 catalyst, urea (4.50 g), Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O (2.02 g), Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O (1.49 g), and ZrO2 (4.93 g) (the molar ratio of urea/Fe/Zn/Zr was 15.0/1.0/1.0/8.0) were added into deionized water of 40 mL under stirring for 4 h. After that, evaporation dried at 120 °C under stirring and calcined at 400 °C for 6 h to obtain the FeZn/ZrO2 sample. Na-FeZn/ZrO2 sample was prepared by impregnating method. Typically, 0.092 g of Na2CO3 was dissolved into deionized water, and then was dropped in the FeZn/ZrO2 (2.0 g) sample, and dried at 60 °C in vacuum for overnight. The obtained catalyst was denoted as Na-FeZn/ZrO2. Besides, the preparation process of other catalysts is the same as the above process, expect that the metal is different. In addition, the Na content on all these FeM/ZrO2 samples was kept at 2 % wt in order to exclude the effect of Na on the catalytic performance (the ICP date for some elements are shown in Table. S1). 2.2 Characterizations The elemental content analyses of the samples were performed with a Varian Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES) equipped with a polytetrafluoroethylene vessel. Before the test, the sample was added with 5 mL of concentrated nitric acid, 3 mL of HCl, 1 mL of HF, and 2 mL of H2O2, and then digested, and cooled to room temperature to be measured. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of as-prepared catalysts were conducted on a Rigaku D/MAX2200PC equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) at 40 kV and 40 mA. The analysis was performed from 10° to 80° with the scanning speed of 10 °·min−1. The phase alterations analysis during the reduction process were employed by an in situ X-ray diffraction (in situ XRD), which was performed on Rigaku SmartLab installed with Cu Kα radiation. Typically, the pure H2 (30 mL·min−1) was introduced into the reaction chamber for 30 min and heated to the reduction temperature with a ramp rate of 20 °C·min−1 under atmospheric pressure. The scanning speed was 10 °·min−1 and recorded ranging from 10° to 80°. The specific surface areas and pore distribution of the synthesized samples were analyzed by N2 adsorption-desorption on JW-BK132F instrument. Prior to the measurement, the samples were evacuated at 350 °C for 4 h to remove possible physically absorbed surface species. The pore distribution and specific surface areas were calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, respectively. The morphologies of the synthesized samples were analyzed using a ZEISS GeminiSEM 300 scanning electron microscope. Prior to the analysis, the samples were dispersed in ethanol and ultrasonicated for 10 min. Oxford Quorum SC7620 sputtering coater was used to spray gold for 45 s with the working current of 10 mA. The microstructure was performed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM; FEI Talos F200X) at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The lattice spacing and particle size were measured using Digital Micrograph and Nano Measurer software. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out by a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument to analyze the reduction behavior of the calcined samples. In brief, the calcined sample of 25 mg was loaded in a U-shaped quartz tube and pretreated with pure Ar (30 mL·min−1) at 350 °C for 1 h, and then cooled to 50 °C with Ar (30 mL·min−1). Subsequently, 10 % H2/Ar (30 mL·min−1) was introduced into the quartz reactor, followed by the sample was heated from 50 °C to 700 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C·min−1 and the TCD signal was recorded. H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD) experiments were carried out after H2 pulse chemisorption experiment on AutoChem II Micomeritics measurement. Typically, 25 mg catalysts were pretreated with 10 vol% H2/Ar flow of 30 mL·min−1 at 400 °C for 30 min, and then the sample was cooled to 50 °C under pure Ar with a flow ratio of 30 mL·min−1, and then started to pulse 10 vol% H2/Ar to record the experimental data. Each pulse was left to return to baseline before the next, and was repeated 20 times. Then the sample was purged with pure Ar (30 mL·min−1) to remove the physically adsorbed CO2. Furthermore, the sample was heated from 50 to 700 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C·min−1 in pure Ar with a flow ratio of 30 mL·min−1 and the TCD signal was recorded. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) measurements were also carried out on the same apparatus as H2-TPD. Typically, 25 mg catalysts were pretreated with 10 vol% H2/Ar flow of 30 mL·min−1 at 400 °C for 30 min, and then the sample was cooled to 50 °C under pure Ar with a flow ratio of 30 mL·min−1. Subsequently, a mixture of 10 vol% CO2/Ar gas with a flow ratio of 30 mL·min−1 was introduced into the quartz reactor at 50 °C for 1 h, followed by the sample was purged with pure Ar (30 mL·min−1) to remove the physically adsorbed CO2. Furthermore, the sample was heated from 50 to 700 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C·min−1 in pure Ar with a flow ratio of 30 mL·min−1 and the TCD signal was recorded. CO temperature-programmed desorption (CO-TPD) measurements were also carried out on the same apparatus as H2-TPD. Typically, 25 mg spent catalysts were pretreated with Ar flow of 30 mL·min−1 at 350 °C for 30 min, and then the sample was cooled to 50 °C. Subsequently, a mixture of 10 vol% CO/Ar gas with a flow ratio of 30 mL·min−1 was introduced into the quartz reactor at 50 °C for 1 h, followed by the sample was purged with pure Ar (30 mL·min−1) to remove the physically adsorbed CO. Furthermore, the sample was heated from 50 to 700 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C·min−1 in pure Ar with a flow ratio of 30 mL·min−1 and the TCD signal was recorded. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on ThermoFisher ESCALAB250 spectrometer equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα radiation source with an anode at operating voltage of 12 kV and current 12 mA. Binding energy for all elements were referenced to the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation CO2 hydrogenation reactions were performed in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor with an internal diameter of 8 mm. In brief, the catalyst of 1.5 g was evenly mixed with quartz sand of 1.0 g, and was loaded in a stainless-steel reactor with internal diameter of 8 mm. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was in-situ reduced at 400 °C for 8 h in a pure H2 flow with 60 mL/min at atmospheric pressure. After reduction, the catalyst was cooled down to 320 °C, and then the reactant gas mixture (gas composition as 25.0 % CO2, 75.0 % H2) was fed into the reactor. The reaction was carried out at the corresponding temperature (320 °C) and pressure (3.0 MPa). The reaction effluents were quantitatively analyzed online with two gas chromatographs (GC-2014C, Shimadzu), one equipped with thermal conductive detector and active charcoal column for Ar, CO, CH4, and CO2 analysis and another equipped with flame ionization detector (FID) to analyze C1-C4 hydrocarbons. Off-line gas chromatographs equipped with FID detector to analyze C5-C13 hydrocarbon. The carbon balances of various reactions were calculated, which were over 90 % for all reactions. Results were calculated as: CO2 conversion (%) = CO 2 inlet − CO 2 outlet CO 2 inlet × 100 % Hydrocarbon selectivity (%) = N C n H m % ∑ 1 n N C n H m × 100 % CO selectivity = CO outlet CO 2 inlet − CO 2 outlet × 100 % where, CO 2 inlet and CO 2 outlet represent moles of CO2 at the inlet and outlet, respectively. CO outlet represents moles of CO at the outlet. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and textural properties N2 adsorption-desorption were preformed to characterize the textural properties of synthesized catalysts and the results are shown in Figure S1 and Table 1. All catalysts exhibited type Ⅳ adsorption isotherms, indicating that the catalysts possessed mesoporous structures. The addition of different metal promoters significantly modified the catalyst textural properties. Na-FeGa/ZrO2 catalyst possessed the largest specific surface area and pore volume of 27.8 m2·g–1 and 0.213 cm3·g–1, respectively. While Na-FeCo/ZrO2 catalyst had the smallest specific surface area and the largest average pore size of 18.8 m2·g–1 and 38.3 nm, respectively. The XRD patterns of prepared catalysts are show in Fig. 1a. These catalysts exhibited diffraction peaks of the ZrO2 phase (JCPDS 86–1449) and Fe2O3 (JCPDS 72–0469). Fresh Na-FeGa/ZrO2, Na-FeMn/ZrO2, Na-FeZn/ZrO2, Na-FeCo/ZrO2 and Na-FeIn/ZrO2 catalysts exhibited Ga2O3 (JCPDS 43–1012); FeMnO3 (JCPDS 76–0076) and Mn2O3 (JCPDS 41–1442); ZnFe2O4 (JCPDS 22–1012); CoFe2O4 (JCPDS 22–1086) and Co3O4 (JCPDS 43–1003); InFeO3 (JCPDS 85–2306), respectively. The formation of different iron spinel oxides reduced the strong metal-support interaction between Fe and ZrO2 [45]. The crystallite sizes calculated by Scherrer formula of the peak at Fe2O3 (110, 35.6), and the results are shown in Table 1. The introduction of promoters reduced the crystallite size of Fe2O3, where the addition of Co reduced the crystallite size from 41.0 nm to 24.5 nm. To investigate the phase compositions of the spent catalysts, the XRD of the spent catalysts was performed, and the results are shown in Fig. 1b. The diffraction peaks belonging to Fe3O4 (JCPDS 19–0629) and Fe5C2 (JCPDS 51–0997) were observed in XRD patterns of all spent catalysts. This result indicated that reduction and carbonization of iron oxides proceed during the reaction to produce the active sites of RWGS and FTS. Unlike the above catalysts, the spent Na-FeMn/ZrO2 catalyst displayed the MnCO3 (JCPDS 83–1763) phase (Fig. S2), which suggested that Mn doping facilitated the formation of carbonate. To observe the surface morphology of the prepared catalysts, we carried out SEM analyses and the results are shown in Fig. 1c-h. The addition of promoters did not affect the microscopic morphology of the catalysts. In addition, 50 metal particles were counted to determine particle sizes (Fig. S3), which indicated that the addition of promoters reduced the size of the metal particles and prevented their agglomeration. In Fig. S4a, the characteristic lattice spacing of Fe3O4 (222), Fe3O4 (422) and Fe5C2 (402) were reflected in the TEM image of spent catalyst Na-FeZn/ZrO2. Meanwhile, Na and Zn were still dispersed more uniformly after the reaction, but Fe appeared to be partially agglomerated in Fig. S4b. 3.2 Reduction behavior We performed H2-TPR to investigate the reduction behavior of the catalysts. In Fig. 2, for the Na-Fe/ZrO2 catalyst, the peaks at around 259 °C, 300–440 °C and 440–635 °C were associated with the Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, Fe3O4 to FeO and FeO to Fe, respectively [46]. Compared with the Na-Fe/ZrO2 catalyst, doping of Mn, Zn, Co and In increased H2 consumption in the lower temperature range (300–450 °C), suggesting that the doping of these metals results in varying degrees of reduction in the Fe-Zr interaction. Meanwhile, for Na-FeCo/ZrO2 catalyst, 300–400 °C and 400–500 °C correspond to Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to Co, respectively [46]. For Na-FeIn/ZrO2 catalyst, 380–500 °C corresponds to the reduction peak of In2O3 [47]. Only Ga doping reduced the reduction capacity of the Fe-based catalysts, owing to the fact that the strong interactions between Fe and Ga inhibited the reduction of Fe oxides [48]. Meanwhile, the low-temperature reduction peak was shifted to high temperature after doping with all metals except Ga, while the hydrogen consumption was significantly increased. These results indicated that the formation of Fe spinel oxides and addition of easily reducible metal oxides were more favorable for the reduction of Fe oxides, while Ga2O3 inhibited the reduction of Fe species. The doping of all metals except Mn caused the high temperature reduction peak from broad pack peaks to narrow peaks. This change may be due to the formation of iron spinel oxides with the metal, reducing the interaction between Fe and support [49,50]. However, the introduction of metal resulted in the high-temperature reduction peak was shifted to high temperature, due to the formation of strong interaction of M (Ga, Mn, Zn, Co and In) metal with Fe-ZrO2. To investigate the physical phase changes during catalyst reduction, we performed in situ XRD experiments on Na-Fe/ZrO2 and Na-FeZn/ZrO2 catalysts at atmospheric pressure ( Figs. 3a and 3b). When the catalysts were reduced below 200 °C, both exhibited clear Fe2O3 peaks (33.2⁰, 35.7⁰ or 30.2⁰, 35.6⁰). Meanwhile, ZnFe2O4 characteristic diffraction peaks (30.2⁰, 35.6⁰, 43.3⁰ and 53.7⁰) were present for the Na-FeZn/ZrO2 catalyst. Where the peaks at 30.2⁰ and 33.2⁰ gradually became weaker and finally vanish as the temperature reached 400 °C. Both of catalysts showed Fe3O4 (34.5⁰), when the temperature was increased to 250 °C. Meanwhile, the Na-FeZn/ZrO2 catalyst showed FeO characteristic diffraction peaks (31.8, 41.6) with increasing temperature. While compared with the reduction process of Na-Fe/ZrO2, no other Fe species were found, indicating that the introduction of Zn reduced the strong metal-support interaction of Fe-ZrO2 and promoted the reduction and carbonization of iron species. Finally, ZnO (36.3⁰, 47.5⁰) appeared at 400 °C [51,52]. 3.3 Adsorption behavior and surface chemical state To verify the H2 adsorption capacity of the as-prepared catalysts during the reaction, H2-TPD and H2 pulsed chemisorption were performed and the results are shown in Fig. 4a and b. In Fig. 4a, the catalyst was saturated after several H2 pulses. Table 2 shows the quantitative results of hydrogen adsorption: Na-FeCo/ZrO2 > Na-FeZn/ZrO2 > Na-FeGa/ZrO2 = Na-FeIn/ZrO2 > Na-Fe/ZrO2 > Na-FeMn/ZrO2. All catalysts had a strong adsorption capacity for H2, due to the high desorption temperature (Fig. 4b). Na-FeCo/ZrO2 catalyst displayed the highest H2 adsorption capacity with a strong and narrow desorption peak at 626 °C, which was attributed to the strong adsorption of the H2 molecules. The activity of the catalyst is closely related to the CO2 adsorption and desorption capacity. CO2-TPD was performed to characterize the basic sites of the catalyst (Fig. 4c). Meanwhile, the amount of CO2 desorption was quantified and is summarized in Table 2. There are predominantly exhibited strongly basic sites (named as γ) in CO2-TPD curves for all catalysts. Moreover, compared with Na-Fe/ZrO2 catalysts, the desorption peaks of Na-FeM/ZrO2 (M=Ga, Mn, Zn and In) catalysts shifted toward a lower temperature, indicating that promoters were more favorable for desorption and activation of CO2 [53]. However, the desorption peaks of Na-FeCo/ZrO2 catalyst shifted toward a higher temperature and displayed broad and narrow strong desorption peaks, indicating that the addition of Co promoted the adsorption capacity of CO2. The CO adsorption and desorption ability is also an important indication of the catalyst activity. The CO-TPD curves of spent catalysts are shown in Fig. 4d, no molecular CO desorption peaks were found in CO-TPD curves of spent catalysts at lower temperatures [54]. The CO desorption peaks mainly appeared around 450–550 °C and 600–680 °C, which were assigned to the adsorption of CO on FexC, and the dissociative adsorption of CO, respectively [55,56]. Na-FeMn/ZrO2, Na-FeZn/ZrO2 and Na-FeCo/ZrO2 catalysts displayed strong CO desorption (CO desorption peaks at 666 °C, 686 °C, and 655 °C), which was beneficial to the CO activation [57]. The above results may be related to the degree of reduction and carbonization of the catalyst. To examine the impact of promoter on the interaction between Fe and ZrO2, we conducted XPS characterization of fresh catalysts. Fig. S5 shows the Zr 3d spectra of the fresh catalysts. Compared with Na-Fe/ZrO2 catalyst, the Zr 3d peaks of heteroatom doped Fe-based catalysts shifted to higher binding energies, indicating that promoted enhance electron transfer from the carrier ZrO2 to the metal. The XPS spectra of Fe 2p for fresh and spent catalysts are shown in Fig. 5a. The peak near 710.7 eV could be ascribed the overlap of Fe2+ and Fe3+ [58]. The peak of Fe-C was near 708.5 eV, while spent catalysts does not presented an obvious characteristic peak [59]. However, compared with the fresh and spent catalysts, Fe 2p of spent catalysts shifted to the low binding energy, suggesting the production of lower-valent iron during the reaction. These results indicated that the oxides of Fe were reduced and carbonized during the reaction. Fig. 5b shows the O 1 s spectra of the spent catalyst surfaces, which exhibited four peaks generally be classified into lattice oxygen (OL, ∼529.3 eV), vacancy oxygen (OV, ∼531.1 eV), adsorbed oxygen (Oad, ∼533.4 eV) [60,61] and C-O in esters, ethers, anhydrides and carboxyl groups (∼535.6 eV) [62,63]. The oxygen vacancy content of the catalyst could be calculated using the equation WOV = AOV / (AOV + AOL) [64]. The WOV of spent Na-FeGa/ZrO2, Na-FeMn/ZrO2, Na-FeZn/ZrO2, Na-FeCo/ZrO2 and Na-FeIn/ZrO2 catalysts were 35.8 %, 46.2 %, 49.2 %, 45.6 % and 35.4 %, respectively. Oxygen vacancies was beneficial to the CO2 adsorption activation. 3.4 Catalytic performance CO2 conversion and products selectivity of synthesized catalysts are shown in Table 3. The Na-Fe/ZrO2 catalyst displayed a good C5+ selectivity (36.1 %), which was attributed to the metal-support interaction between Fe-ZrO2, which facilitated the dispersion of the active metal. Among the catalysts modified with promoters. The Na-FeCo/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited the highest CO2 conversion (40.6 %) and lowest CO selectivity (7.4 %), with CH4 selectivity of 83.0 %. These results indicated that Co doping not only promoted CO2 adsorption and activation but also significantly reduced CO selectivity. The stronger hydrogenation ability of Co reduced the O/P ratio of the C2-C4 and significantly increased the CH4 selectivity. The Na-FeZn/ZrO2 catalyst possessed the highest O/P ratio, suggesting that the addition of Zn facilitates the generation of light olefins. Na-FeMn/ZrO2 exhibited a higher O/P ratio and a lower C5+ selectivity, which was attributed to the weak interaction of CO with the catalyst and the lower ratio of carbon species on the catalyst surface, which inhibited chain growth [65]. Na-FeIn/ZrO2 showed the highest C5+ selectivity of 40.0 %, CO selectivity of 9.5 %, and CH4 selectivity of 21.6 %. However, the addition of Ga did not result in the expected performance enhancement, with CO2 conversion was only 18.8 %, with CO and CH4 selectivities of 67.9 % and 56.6 %, respectively, and an O/P ratio as low as 0.35. This negative result was attributed to Ga inhibited the reduction and carbonization of Fe oxides. The modulation pattern of CO2 hydrogenation of Na-Fe/ZrO2 catalysts doped with different heteroatom catalysts are summarized in Fig. 6. Combined with a series of characterization results of the catalysts, Na-FeGa/ZrO2 catalyst possessed a strong adsorption capacity for H2, but a weak adsorption capacity for CO2. This result indicated that the strong Fe-Ga interaction inhibits the reduction and carbonization of Fe species, resulting in reduced CO2 activation and C-C coupling capacity. Meanwhile, the conclusion is similar to previous studies that the addition of Ga inhibits the formation of metallic iron and iron carbide [66], which is due to the presence of an ultrathin Ga-oxide layer on the surface of the metal during the CO2 hydrogenation process [67], as well as the fact that Ga has a strong interactions with Pt and Fe, and that a portion of the form of Ga3+ is still present even after the reduction [66,68]. However, this is diametrically opposed to “the addition of Ga promotes the reduction and carbonization of iron” [69], which may be due to the fact that the Ga sites in GaZrOx provide the necessary hydrogenation sites to promote the hydrogenation of the intermediates [70]. Compared with the Na-Fe/ZrO2 catalysts, Na-FeCo/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited a stronger reduction capacity and CO2 adsorption capacity. However, their hydrogenation capacity and weak chain growth capacities were not improved, resulting in high CH4 selectivity. In addition, Mn and In possessed weak methanation activity. The addition of Mn and In enhanced the reduction and carbonation capacity of catalysts, which promoted the adsorption activation of CO intermediates and the generation of hydrocarbons. It is noteworthy that Na-FeMn/ZrO2 catalyst showed MnCO3 phase after the reaction, which may be related to the fact that the addition of Mn promotes the generation of oxygenated compounds [71]. For Na-FeZn/ZrO2 catalysts, a higher oxygen vacancy concentration facilitated the activation of CO2. Meanwhile, Zn species promoted the carburization and CO chemisorption of Fe, which in turn facilitated the generation of olefins [65]. Comparison of previous studies revealed (detailed performance comparison data in Table S2) that the incorporation of Zn and Mn helped to improve olefins selectivity, and the incorporation of Co was effective in increasing CO2 conversion and decreasing CO selectivity. In permitted more C-C couplings [72], and Ga had a different role when interacting with different metals. We implemented multiple catalytic performance tests to verify the reproducibility of the catalytic data, and the results were summarized in Table S3. From these data, it is clear that the catalytic performance of prepared catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation is well reproducible. 4 Conclusions In this work, the heteroatom promoted Na-Fe/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared by the urea self-combustion method, and they were used for CO2 hydrogenation. The characterization results revealed that the introduction of heteroatom into the Na-Fe/ZrO2 catalysts could significantly enhance physiochemical properties, and the strong interaction of various active sites. Ga possessed strong interaction with Fe and inhibited the reduction and carbonization of Fe oxides. Among them, Zn, Co and In reduced the strong interactions between Fe and ZrO2, which promoted the adsorption activation of H2 and CO2. Meanwhile, the Na-FeM/ZrO2 (Mn, Zn and In) of spent catalysts increases the adsorption intensity of CO, which significantly increased the O/P ratio. Therefore, the addition of Zn favored olefins production with an O/P ratio of 4.93, and the addition of Co and In facilitated CO2 conversion and the decrease in CO selectivity. The results will provide support and direction for the development of catalyst for CO2 activation. CRediT authorship contribution statement Yaqin Xing: Formal analysis, Data curation. coredata.dc:description: Although heteroatom doped Fe-based catalysts have made significant process in CO2 hydrogenation, designing a tailor-made catalyst with excellent catalytic performance remains a challenge. In this work, a series of heteroatom doped Na-FeM/ZrO2 (M = Ga, Mn, Zn, Co, and In) catalysts were prepared by the urea self-combustion method. Meanwhile, the structure and physicochemical properties of these catalysts were analyzed by various characterizations. In detail, Zn doping was more favorable for light olefin production. Na-FeZn/ZrO2 catalysts exhibited CO2 conversion of 31.3 % and light olefins selectivity of 41.4 % with olefins/paraffins (O/P) ratio of 4.93. H2-TPR and in situ XRD results revealed that Zn promoted reduction of the catalyst and the formation of ZnO species, which inhibited the secondary hydrogenation of the generated olefins. This work contributes to the development of novel catalysts for efficient CO2 hydrogenation via understanding the relationship between structure and catalytic performance.
